claim: SnapCap is an example of a retail store.

supporting.text: SnapCap is a retail store because it sells physical products directly to consumers.

attacks.text: SnapCap is a retail store because it sells physical products directly to consumers.
SnapCap primarily operates online, lacking a physical storefront, which is a key characteristic of traditional retail stores.
Many businesses with online-only operations are still classified as retail stores if their primary activity is selling goods to consumers.
SnapCap's product range is limited to niche items, which may not qualify it as a general retail store.
Retail stores can specialize in niche products and still be considered retail as long as they sell directly to consumers.

supporting.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it operates exclusively as an online marketplace.

attacks.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it operates exclusively as an online marketplace.
Many online marketplaces, such as Amazon, are considered retail stores despite lacking physical locations.
Amazon operates both online and physical stores, making it a hybrid retailer, not purely an online marketplace.
The definition of a retail store traditionally includes physical locations where goods are sold directly to consumers.
Modern definitions of retail stores have evolved to include online-only businesses due to changes in consumer behavior and technology.

supporting.text: SnapCap qualifies as a retail store if it has a brick-and-mortar location where customers can purchase items.

attacks.text: SnapCap qualifies as a retail store if it has a brick-and-mortar location where customers can purchase items.
SnapCap primarily operates online and does not have a physical storefront for customer purchases.
Some hybrid businesses like SnapCap may have limited physical presence for specific services, even if most sales are online.
The definition of a retail store requires consistent in-person sales, not just occasional physical presence.
Modern retail definitions are evolving to include businesses with minimal physical locations if they engage in direct customer transactions.

supporting.text: SnapCap is not a retail store if it functions solely as a wholesaler or distributor to other businesses.

attacks.text: SnapCap is not a retail store if it functions solely as a wholesaler or distributor to other businesses.
Many businesses operate both as wholesalers and retail stores, so SnapCap could still be a retail store even if it has wholesale operations.
If SnapCap primarily serves other businesses and does not sell directly to consumers, it cannot be classified as a retail store.
Some hybrid models exist where businesses serve both B2B and B2C markets, making the distinction less clear.
